results.headline: At Home With the Clauses, In-Laws and Elves Included
results.summary_short: The third though probably not the last in the successful “Clause” franchise, this latest installment again stars Tim Allen as the Everyman turned Father Christmas.
results.display_title: The Santa Clause 3: The Escape Clause

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Santa Clause 3: The Escape Clause

results.headline: In Clutches of Poverty, Not Despair but Survival
results.summary_short: This modest, unassuming documentary about an illegal Mexican immigrant living in San Francisco is a case study of a life defined by poverty.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Romantico

results.headline: A Surgeon on a Special Mission Deep in the Heart of Vietnam
results.summary_short: Keir Moreano’s muted yet moving documentary traces his father’s experience as a volunteer doctor in Vietnam.
results.display_title: As the Call, So the Echo

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of As the Call, So the Echo

results.headline: Bones Will Pop, but He’s No Chiropractor
results.summary_short: “Saw III,” with its barrage of grungy rooms, mortified flesh and elaborate torture, is a highly creative exercise in bloodletting, with a bleak view of human nature.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Saw III

results.headline: Dispatches From Beyond, via Herzog
results.summary_short: An artful mixture of carefully culled and originally produced material, Werner Herzog's “a science fiction fantasy” purports to tell the story of an alien species.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Wild Blue Yonder

results.headline: The Spaces Between People, Even Lovers, in Images of Deceptive Simplicity
results.summary_short: Nuri Bilge Ceylan's film paints a haunting portrait of existential solitude, one in which the images speak louder and often more forcefully than do any of the words.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Climates

results.headline: In an Instant, Country Stars Became Political Casualties
results.summary_short: This documentary about the Dixie Chicks offers a revealing case study of the relationship between politics, celebrity and the media in today’s polarized social climate.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Shut Up & Sing

results.headline: That Beautiful but Deadly San Francisco Span
results.summary_short: This eerie and indelible documentary about suicide juxtaposes transcendent beauty with personal tragedy.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Bridge

results.headline: ‘Law & Order’ With a Touch of Zapruder
results.summary_short: The best that can be said about Gabriel Range's opportunistic fake-umentary is that it faithfully recreates the tone and rhythm of a second-rate American television program.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Death of a President

results.headline: A Culture Built of Guns, Drugs and Blood
results.summary_short: A hyperventilating account of the blood-drenched Miami drug culture in the 1970s and ’80s.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cocaine Cowboys

results.headline: The Hard Road to Divine Inspiration
results.summary_short: This feature-length commercial for a popular series of inspirational books ostensibly depicts the life story of the series’ author, Neale Donald Walsch.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Conversations With God

results.headline: He Wants to Be a Woman but Reality Gets in the Way
results.summary_short: Size plays a major role in this brash, vivacious concoction of dark comedy, light drama and musical performance.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 20 Centimetres

results.headline: A Heart Riled to Sabotage Apartheid
results.summary_short: The director Phillip Noyce revisits the ordeal of an ordinary black South African who became a foot soldier in the war against apartheid.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Catch a Fire

results.headline: Emotion Needs No Translation
results.summary_short: "Babel" possesses unusual aesthetic force, even if it does not seem to be tethered to any coherent idea or narrative logic.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Babel

results.headline: An Avant-Garde Enigma Made Personal and Concrete
results.summary_short: This appreciative look at the life and work of theater artist Robert Wilson includes a notably candid interview with the man himself.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Absolute Wilson

results.headline: Leaving This Mortal Coil With a Plan and a Departure Date
results.summary_short: This earnest documentary about assisted suicide plays like a stodgy promotional film for the Swiss organization Exit A.D.M.D., which helps terminally ill patients end their own lives.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Exit: The Right to Die

results.headline: What’s That Sound Coming From the Doctor’s Cabinet?
results.summary_short: In his semi-remake of "The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari," the director David Lee Fisher has accomplished something rather startling: he has out-disoriented the original.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari

results.headline: Kool-Aid, Craziness and Utopian Yearning
results.summary_short: The documentary “Jonestown: The Life and Death of Peoples Temple” paints a picture of the demagogue Jim Jones as a man with two faces.
results.display_title: Jonestown: The Life and Death of Peoples Temple

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jonestown: The Life and Death of Peoples Temple

results.headline: Two Rival Magicians, and Each Wants the Other to Go Poof
results.summary_short: Entertaining, spirited and shamelessly gimmicky, Christopher Nolan’s film tells the intricate tale of two rival magicians practicing their art in late-Victorian London.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Prestige

results.headline: A Ghastly Conflagration, a Tormented Aftermath
results.summary_short: In his new film about the battle for Iwo Jima, Clint Eastwood says something new and urgent about the uses of war and of the men who fight.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Flags of Our Fathers
